li.p: What kinds of technology are used by mathematicians and data scientists?
What is the structure of a Jupyter notebook, and how are Jupyter notebooks used in mathematics and data science?

statement.p: Throughout this course, you will complete the activities from this text within Jupyter notebooks hosted on CoCalc.com, some individually, and some within groups. Your first activity is to set these Jupyter notebooks up for yourself!

li.p: First, either create an account at CoCalc.com, or log in with the account provided by your instructor.
Go to TODO https://share.cocalc.com/share/d17525â€¦, and use the Open in CoCalc button to create a new project with your notebooks for the course.

Open the Settings for this project, and add your instructor's account as a Collaborator. This allows them to see your work, and unlock the premium features required for this course (such as importing data from other websites to analyze).

Finally, navigate to the notebook associated with this activity. (You may need to select a kernel to open it; that choice is not important for now, so pick anything.) In the editable textbox appearing below this activity in the notebook, double-click to edit, erase any default content, and type the well-worn phrase of computing: Hello World!. Tap Shift+Enter to save your note.

introduction.p: Jupyter notebooks consist of cells that can include either writing or code. Let's explore how writing code in Jupyter works.

task.p: To write and execute code, your notebook needs to have a kernel, that is, an associated programming language. Select a Python 3 kernel from the notebook menu. (If there are multiple versions of Python 3 available, it doesn't matter which one you choose. Do not choose a Python 2 kernel, however.)
Once you've done this, edit the contents of the below cell to read import sys; sys.version and hit Shift+Enter.

Most likely, the result of entering the code import sys; sys.version into the above cell just make the text import sys; sys.version appear. This is because the editable cells in this notebook are set to Markdown mode by default, which is used for writing text, such as the paragraph you're currently reading. (If the above cell wasn't already in Markdown mode, use the menu to switch it to Markdown mode, so the output is simply import sys; sys.version.)

Now enter import sys; sys.version into the below cell, and use the menu to switch the cell type to Code. Now using Shift+Enter should display something like '3.6.9 (default, Apr 18 2020, 01:56:04) \n[GCC 8.4.0]', the version of the Python kernel you selected.
Each task in these notebooks includes a single editable Markdown cell by default. However, you may add as many Markdown and Code cells as you like by clicking above or below an existing cell.
Enter The value of 1+1 is: into the below Markdown cell. Then create a Code cell below it with the contents 1+1 to calculate the result.

introduction.p: Jupyter notebooks provide a convenient interface for communiating mathematics and data science. The Jupyter server CoCalc.com also provides access to a full Linux environment, which you can access from your browser without installing anything on your computer.

task.p: To access the Linux command-line interface, go to Files and create a new Terminal file.

We can use the Linux command-line program cat to display information about the version of Linux being run, which is stored in the file /etc/os-release. To do this, enter cat /etc/os-release in your terminal. Copy and paste the results (which should include a line such as PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS") into the below cell. (It's okay if the line breaks pasted from the terminal don't appear in the output below; we will explore Markdown formatting in a later activity.)

You can upload any files you need to CoCalc, which can then be used by your notebooks. Use a search engine to find an image of a Klein bottle on the internet. Download a copy of this image to your computer. Using the New menu option in CoCalc, upload a copy of this image to the server, in the same folder as this notebook's file.

Make this image display in the below Markdown cell by entering ![Klein bottle](image.png), replacing image.png with the filename of the image you uploaded. (The text Klein bottle is used to describe the image in case it doesn't load, or for those using a screen reader.)
Now create a new file called data.csv in the same folder as this notebook. Copy-paste the text from into this new file to save a Comma-Separated Values spreadsheet.
Then copy-paste the text from into a Code cell below to use this data in a Python 3 script to display the temperatures in Celcius.

p.cd: import csv with open("data.csv", "r") as csv_file: rows = csv.DictReader(csv_file, delimiter=',') for row in rows: temp = format((float(row["TempInF"])-32)*5/9, '.2f') print("The temperature at "+row["Time"]+" is "+temp+" degrees Celcius.")
